importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Millennium Seed Bank was opened by the Prince of Wales in 2000, marking the beginning of a global effort to conserve plant biodiversity.
The seed bank helped restore plant species after intense wildfires in Australia in 2019, demonstrating its real-world impact on environmental recovery.
The article was published on October 19, 2025, highlighting the ongoing relevance and expanding importance of the seed bank's work in the current environmental climate.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 25-year anniversary of the Millennium Seed Bank in 2025 underscores its long-term commitment to global plant conservation and environmental restoration.

keyTakeAways: The Millennium Seed Bank (MSB) at Wakehurst Botanic Garden holds over 2.5 billion seeds from 40,000 wild plant species, serving as a critical safeguard against plant extinction.
The MSB was established in 2000 and opened by the Prince of Wales, with its original vision of being a 'doomsday vault' now evolving into active restoration of degraded ecosystems globally.
The seed bank has contributed to ecological recovery efforts, including post-wildfire restoration in Australia and the restoration of rare chalk grasslands on the South Downs.
The project operates across all major biomes—from sea level to 5,000 meters and from poles to tropics—showing a truly global scope of environmental intervention.

Cate Blanchett, a celebrated Hollywood actress, has become an ambassador for the MSB, engaging with researchers and learning hands-on seed storage techniques, demonstrating public outreach and cross-sector influence.
The work of the MSB offers tangible hope in a world facing biodiversity loss, with Blanchett noting that the seed bank represents a 'good news story' rooted in real-world environmental action.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Cate Blanchett, a celebrated Hollywood actress, has become a passionate ambassador for the Millennium Seed Bank (MSB) at Wakehurst Botanic Garden in Sussex, UK, as the project celebrates its 25th anniversary. The MSB, opened in 2000 by the Prince of Wales, houses over 2.5 billion seeds from 40,000 wild plant species and plays a vital role in both preserving biodiversity and restoring degraded ecosystems worldwide. After being inspired by the landscape and conservation efforts at Wakehurst, Blanchett has personally engaged with seed storage and restoration projects, including efforts to restore rare chalk grasslands in the South Downs and assist in post-wildfire recovery in Australia. The article highlights how the MSB has evolved from a doomsday vault to a living tool for environmental regeneration, offering tangible hope in the face of climate change and species extinction. Blanchett describes the seed bank as a 'good news story,' emphasizing that real change is possible and underway.
title: Cate Blanchett: In praise of the humble seed
